ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: while the course was conducted through live, synchronous lectures, I learned best from the recorded lectures from previous years, as well as the recordings of the live lectures from this semester. Recorded lectures just make it easier for me to go at my own pace, I can pause and rewind, and make sure I really understand a concept before moving on.
The lectures are very valuable. The interpersonal communication between classmates and Professor Koker was instrumental in understanding difficult concepts.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The obvious knowledge and skills that I learned during this course related to quantitive reasoning and mathematical relationships; however, another valuable part of this course is learning how to apply these concepts to social issues. Learning that application is very useful in writing.
I gained a better understanding of economic models and the math behind them.
I learned the foundations of Microeconomics focusing in on consumer and production theory.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strength of this course is the attention to students, as well as the survey elements. The weakness of this course is primarily in the pacing of the last half of the course.

Professor Tolga Koker is, without question, the most committed professor that I could have asked for. Additionally, his subject-matter expertise and commitment to increasing the well-being of his students allows him to connect with his class.

There are no weaknesses in this class.
Strengths are the office hours and the instructors strong teaching skills. I would recommend  better preparation for the problem sets and finals to improve the class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think everything was to standard.
There were really  helpful virtual office hours.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes; this course has been very insightful in how I view economics and has provided a great survey of the topic.
Absolutely. For someone with no calculus knowledge that is interested in microeconomics, there is no better course.
I would recommend this cksss due to the skills it equips you with.
I would; it is a good intro to Econ course in a seminar setting.
